Award.AwardTitle: CCSS: Collaborative Research: Stochastic Modeling and Optimization for Cognitive Radio Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop network protocols and optimization
techniques to efficiently utilize the spectrum white spaces for cognitive radio networks.
The proposed approach is based on a novel cognitive radio network (CRN) network
architecture under which effective design methodologies can be developed to take better
advantage of cognitive radio technologies in harvesting and managing unutilized
spectrum for better service provisioning.

The PIs will first study the proposed CRN architecture to enable collective spectrum
sensing and let the secondary service provider manage the harvested spectrum for better
spectral efficiency while shifting the design complexity from the user side to the system
side. They will then investigate how to split traffic over harvested spectral bands to
balance the risk and reward, how to optimally utilize the spectral resource by jointly
designing frequency allocation and routing while supporting traffic demands, and how to
maximize the throughput by joint link scheduling and routing. The proposed research
outcome will lay the solid foundation for practical implementation of CRNs, which could
potentially revolutionizes the way how cognitive radios should be more effectively used.

The research outcome will significantly advance the state of the art in CRNs, opening a
new avenue to designing smart living environments for public safety, disaster rescue,
mobile healthcare and online social networks to improve peoples quality of life.
Research findings will be disseminated through publications and talks, and in classroom
teaching. This project will also actively recruit and train minority students for future
workforce and mentor junior faculty.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cognitive radios (CRs) have attracted tremendous interest in the last few years due to the possibility of utilizing the unused licensed spectrum (called white spaces). Existing research mostly focuses on the premise that the end users carry cognitive radios which can sense the white spaces, select the spectrum band and carry out communications accordingly without affecting the normal communications for the licensed band users (called the primary users). This is of course an interesting vision assuming that cognitive radios can be made significantly small and be implemented in commonly used mobile devices. Unfortunately, there are some practical issues which may deter the deployment of the cognitive radio networks or lead to less efficient cognitive radio network design. In particular, cognitive capability may not be easily embedded into light-weight small-sized end user radios operating in significantly separated spectrum bands as assumed by most existing research. Besides, even if we could have such radios for end users, it would still be challenging to gather spectrum vacancy information on their own, to enforce any contractual agreement on the opportunistic short-term use of the licensed band, and not to interfere with primary services. Moreover, most research activities only study one-hop transmissions in CR networks, but lack deep understanding of multi-hop end-to-end service provisioning. Finally, there has been intensive research on spectrum auction recently. But it is not clear how such spectrum trading can be implemented in practical systems. In order to make the proposed auction mechanisms work, there must be viable infrastructure in place to support such spectrum auctioning activities, which does not seem to exist yet.

 

The Intellectual Merit of this Project: In this project, we have proposed a novel cognitive radio network (CRN) architecture which can enable collective spectrum harvesting via spectrum auction and efficient spectrum utilization while shifting the design complexity from the user side to the system side. We then introduce the secondary service provider (SSP) to manage the potentially stochastic spectrum due to the uncertain return of primary users (PUs) and to enable users without cognitive radio capability to also access the CRN services by deploying cognitive mesh routing facilities. Under this novel architectural design, we have investigated how to allocate service traffic to stochastic spectrum to balance the risk and reward, how to optimally utilize the spectrum by jointly designing frequency allocation and routing to minimize the purchased spectrum while supporting traffic demands, and how to maximize the throughput by joint link scheduling and routing under uncertain spectrum availability. The proposed research not only yields a novel approach to the effective design of CRNs, but also develops a new set of communication technologies to design the future anywhere and anytime smart environment for bettering our quality of life.

 

The Broader Impacts of this Project: This research project effort has yielded tremendous impacts in many aspects. First, as CRNs have been incorporated into many telecommunications legacy systems, such as the cellular systems and Wi-Fi networks, for future wireless Internet, leading to the emergence of smart living environments, the resulting future integrated networks can support much more varieties of services with more flexible qualities of services and provide ubiquitous access opportunity, which is crucial for applications such as urban sensing for public safety and disaster recovery, mobile healthcare and mobile social networks. The developed technologies will definitely help this realization.
